data.title: Board — Larkspur Conservation: Tennessee's Conservation and Natural Burial
data.meta_description: Meet the community leaders who guide the development of Larkspur.
data.meta_site_name: Larkspur Conservation: Tennessee's Conservation and Natural Burial
data.text:
Becca Stevens (Chair)

Becca is an Episcopal priest, social entrepreneur, speaker, and author. Becca serves as chaplain of St. Augustine’s at Vanderbilt University and is the founder of Magdalene, a residential community for women who have survived prostitution, trafficking, and addiction. She serves as executive director of its social enterprise, Thistle Farms. To date, Becca has raised more than $15 million and gained nationwide press coverage for the organizations she supports. Becca was named “Nashvillian of the Year” and “Tennessean of the Year” by the Nashville Scene and The Tennessean respectively. She was recently designated a White House “Champion of Change” and inducted into the Tennessee Women’s Hall of Fame. In 2016 she was named a CNN Hero. Becca lives in Nashville, where she and her husband, Grammy-winning song writer Marcus Hummon, raised their three sons. Her blog is available at BeccaStevens.org.

Jason Dinger (President)

Jason is a social entrepreneur committed to building sustainable enterprises that address global social challenges. Whether delivering internet technologies to isolated communities, sustainable health care solutions in low-income countries or access to prescription medications for uninsured individuals, Jason’s wide-eyed curiosity around what’s possible and pragmatic leveraging of market forces continues to bring new innovations to underserved communities near and far.Jason is the SVP for Strategy and Innovation with AmerisourceBergen, a Fortune 10 company committed to providing healthier futures for millions of people and animals around the world. Prior to serving in his current role, Jason served as the SVP of Product Management and Innovation for Ascension, CEO of MissionPoint Health Partners, and CEO of the Dispensary of Hope – the nation’s first not-for-profit distributor of medicines for poor and uninsured individuals.

"I believe it is efforts like Larkspur that can bring us together through life's most meaningful of transitions. My own spiritual practice rests on truths of interdependence and impermanence; touchstones I have found to be a wellspring of both hope and wisdom, touchstones I feel Larkspur brings alive in service to our community."

Tara Armistead (Vice President)

Tara has a keen love of nature combined with an artist’s eye for detail. She launched her own landscape architecture firm in Nashville in 1987 and currently serves on the board of The Nature Conservancy and the Nashville Civic Design Center. She has worked on the design and preservation of Nashville’s Warner Parks. Tara is guided by an ethic to be a good steward of the land, challenging herself and others, with a keen eye to local sustainability. When designing landscapes, her projects often span family generations, giving a quality of longevity and sustainability to her work. She designs landscapes that deepen the connection between nature and culture by listening, collaborating, and creating.

Kim Bailey (Secretary)

Kim has been a naturalist at Warner Park Nature Center since 1996 and is an avid hiker, cyclist, photographer and explorer of the natural world. Her powerful childhood connection to nature led to a lifetime commitment to educate others about the beauty and importance of the natural world. She was named Tennessee Environmental Educator of the year in 2008 by the Tennessee Environmental Education Association for her work with teachers and students of all ages. She co-wrote the Tennessee Environmental Literacy Plan in 2012 with educators from across the state and chaired the Environmental Stewardship Plan for the Middle TN Presbytery in 1992. After earning an MA from Vanderbilt in Biology with a focus on Ecology, Kim raised 2 sons before joining the nature center staff. Serving on the board of Larkspur is a natural extension of Kim’s life-long connection with the earth and advocacy for its protection.

Nathan Greene (Treasurer)

Nathan is a CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER™ and principal of Cairn Financial Group. He has nearly 10 years of experience in the financial services industry and has built his practice with the sole purpose of enabling wealth success in his clients’ lives – no matter their definition of “wealth.” Nathan is a graduate of Auburn University and is a regular teacher, speaker, and commentator on financial matters. He is a leader in the industry as he currently serves as President of the Board of the Financial Planning Association of Middle Tennessee, leads a number of national committees, and teaches in the CFP® program at Belmont University. He has met the extensive experience, education, ethics, and training requirements of the CFP Board of Standards required to hold the prestigious CFP® certification, and above all, Nathan is committed to the fiduciary standard of ensuring his advice is in your best interest. “The mission of Larkspur lines up perfectly with my own passions, so I am excited about the potential opportunity to make an impact in a way that matters.”

John Stone (Director)

John is an attorney who has lived and worked in Nashville since 1984, where his primary fields of practice are commercial real estate and the representation of privately-owned businesses. He and his wife Mary have been actively involved with environmental and conservation groups in Tennessee for the past 25 years. He has served on the boards of the Tennessee Environmental Action Fund and the Tennessee Environmental Council. In 1995, Mayor Phil Bredesen appointed John as one of the initial directors of The Metropolitan Nashville and Davidson County Solid Waste Region Board and he served as chairman of that board through the end of Mayor Bredesen’s term. He is also past chair and currently a member of the Board of Directors of Goodwill Industries of Middle Tennessee, Inc., and his wife Mary currently serves as a member of the board of directors of the Harpeth River Watershed Association. A native Tennessean, Mr. Stone earned his undergraduate degree from Vanderbilt University and his law degree from Emory University. His interest in Larkspur stems from his belief in the environmental and societal benefits natural burial and his commitment to Larkspur’s long-term vision of land conservation for future generations.

Dr. Mohana Karlekar (Director)

Mohana is the Section Chief of Palliative Care at Vanderbilt University Medical Center and is the Associate Program Director for the Hospice and Palliative Care Fellowship. She has been on faculty at VUMC for 12 years. She earned her MD from SUNY at Stony Brook and completed internal medicine residency training at Mt. Sinai Medical Center in New York. She is currently the chair of the state palliative care task force and is a member of the American Association for the Surgery Trauma's Palliative Care Committee.

“The relationships we build in the moments we intersect with our patients, their families, and friends I think can be pivotal and allow for incredible human connection and hopefully incredible impact on their lives. It seems to me Larkspur as an organization and mission strives for many of the same things we strive for in palliative care; personalized care that is focused on one’s individual goals and values. Like palliative care, Larkspur promotes a true celebration of life in a way that is truly unique. As a culture, we are all very good at celebrating birth, the inception of life, but unfortunately, as a whole, we tend not to be as comfortable ushering in death and being intentional on what we want at the end of our lives. I believe that organizations like Larkspur can help move the needle.”

Amanda Rosenberger (Director)

Amanda is an Aquatic Ecologist and Conservation Biologist. Her research interests are in the ecology and conservation of freshwater biota, including fish, mussels, and crayfish, with an emphasis on the role of ecological processes in shaping organisms’ distributions, population characteristics, and community structure. Her current position is as Assistant Fisheries Unit Leader and Professor of Biology at Tennessee Technological University in Cookeville, TN. Her research program focuses on the landscape ecology and management of Tennessee’s freshwater mussels and nongame fish. Tennessee has a unique natural heritage – it is the cradle of biodiversity in the temperate world, with a disproportionate number of aquatic species – animals she loves to illustrate when she can find the time. To assist in the preservation and conservation of Tennessee’s natural heritage is truly her vocation and passion. In addition to Scientist, Amanda identifies as a Mother, Daughter, Spouse, and Survivor of gun violence. Members of her family have lived in Tennessee for over 30 years, and much of her ancestry is in this part of the world. Her beloved father was buried at Taylor Hollow under the care of Larkspur Conservation in January of 2022.

Katie Radel (Director)

Katie Radel is the Founder of Ripple Consulting Group, a public relations firm in Nashville. Katie founded Ripple Consulting Group to help companies and individuals tell their story and have a positive relationship with their audience and community. She believes that stories and relationships can cause long-term, positive ripple effects.Katie has more than 20 years of experience leading public relations and marketing initiatives for Fortune 500 companies, small businesses, startups, and nonprofits. In addition to serving on the Larkspur Conservation board, she serves on the board of Nashville Women in Healthcare, and she is an advisory board member for Saddle Up!

Katie’s first job was working at her family’s funeral home. She is passionate about combining her background, experience, and passion for celebrating life to be a steward for Larkspur Conservation.

Joseph B. Fanning (Director)

Joseph B. Fanning, Ph.D. is Associate Professor of Medicine in the Center for Biomedical Ethics and Society at Vanderbilt University Medical Center. Joe received undergraduate training at Birmingham-Southern College, completed masters work at Princeton Theological Seminary, and earned his doctorate in the Graduate Department of Religion at Vanderbilt University. His research focuses on the role of communication and interpersonal skills in the development of therapeutic relationships across clinical contexts. Most recently he has co-authored a book based on fifty-five patient interviews titled, What Patients Teach: The Everyday Ethics of Healthcare. Fanning also teaches healthcare ethics across Vanderbilt working with students in the schools of Medicine and Nursing as well as with trainees across multiple residency and fellowship programs. He is also the lead instructor for the undergraduate course in the College of Arts and Science titled “Death and Dying in America” that combines experiential learning through hospice volunteering with interdisciplinary engagement of the issues that surround death and dying.

“Sharing Larkspur's distinctive vision, over the last several years, with my friends and family has felt like sharing an idea whose time has come; broadening the awareness of Larkspur’s mission as a board member allows me to participate more fully in this vital work.”

Don Welch (Emeritus)

Don serves as President of the St. Augustine's Chapel Advisory Board, following a 35-year career at Vanderbilt University as an associate dean. With a joint appointment as professor of law and professor of religion, Don taught courses in the fields of ethics and public policy, and law and religion. His fifth book, A Guide to Ethics and Public Policy: Finding Our Way, was published in 2014. He is the recipient of the Vanderbilt Law School’s Distinguished Service Award and Baylor University’s Men and Women of Merit Award. His involvement in Larkspur Conservation reconnects him with the journey that brought him to Nashville in 1969 to become a student at Vanderbilt Divinity School.

Father Charles Strobel (In Memoriam)

Charlie is best known as the founder of Room In The Inn. It all began in the winter of 1985, when he opened the doors of his parish to individuals seeking sanctuary in the church parking lot. This simple act of kindness marked the beginning of Room In The Inn. In December 1986, four congregations committed to sheltering people experiencing homeless through March 1987. By the end of that winter, 31 congregations had joined. Now, Room In The Inn has nearly 200 congregations from a wide variety of traditions and over 7,000 volunteers who shelter almost 1,500 men and women from November 1 through March 31 each season.
